message.title: (!) Crassus (!)
message.subtitle: Trade Emporium
message.text: @G[c3 stills_36.png]@L @H Message @L Governor, the Republic is prospering yet your city, blessed with deposits of gold and other metals, is still a backwater not able to even process its own goods. @L@L Let me introduce myself, my name is Marcus Licinius Crassus. Patricians in the Senate call me the wealthiest man in Rome, but I would say it is not my chief quality as fortunes do not build themselves: I look at the burned out insulae and see potential. @L@L I look at Tarsus and see all that it could become. Let me sponsor your endeavor. @L@L I will acquire construction materials and see them transported to your warehouses, while you in turn build a caravanserai to accommodate traders. Exports of local metals will help my other industrial assets greatly. @L@L Any materials left over from the construction are of course yours to use as you please. The only thing I ask in return is that, when the time comes, you will reciprocate and assist me in one of my endeavors. @L@L @G[decorative objetive .png] @H New Side Objective @L Option 1 - Place a caravanserai foundation to accept the deal. If you do so, you will receive the promised materials: prepare storage space for 32 timber, stone, and bricks. Once accepted, you must finish the construction within 3 years or face the wrath of Crassus. @L@L Option 2 - Do not place a caravanserai foundation within a year to ignore the deal. This will upset Crassus moderately. @L@L Option 3 - Accept the deal by building a caravanserai, take the materials, but do not build the monument, effectively backstabbing Crassus. This will cause a single attack from Roman forces. @G[caravanserai.png] @G[decorative objetive .png] @L@L @H Historical Background @L Crassus was known as the richest man in Rome at this time of his life. He was heavily involved with land ownership, renting, and tax collection. Famously, he funded his own fire watch who would only help fight fires if the person sold the rights to Crassus. @L@L Roman tax collection was not as centralized as we might think as governors would often collect tariffs and tax, and corruption and embezzlement were rampant and even expected. @L@L Politicians mostly wanted either profitable eastern assignments to harvest trade tariffs, or provinces that had the potential of conquests, as war could be extremely profitable due to enslaving prisoners of war. @L@L On the topic of tax collection, it was contracted out to private companies who would try to estimate how much tax they would be able to collect from an area of the Republic. This led to companies purposely overestimating to get the contract, which ended up with massive debts. Crassus as well as other influential Romans were heavily involved with these companies. @L@L Rome was not exclusive in this however, as many if not all ancient societies had poor understanding of economics as we know them today. A solution to accumulated debts was to abolish all debt after a time to clean the books and reset the economy. This was unpopular with landowners but often a necessary mechanism; you can think of it as an amnesty of indebted people. @L@L Citizens could even become enslaved if they had too much debt. Slaves would be considered the property of their master, without any repercussions for harming or exploiting them. This topic is highly unpleasant for us to think about today, but it deserves a mention as it was a vital part of Roman society and in fact most ancient civilizations had similar systems. @L@L@L@L
